article.headline: Coronavirus tally: Global cases of COVID-19 top 17.3 million, 673,568 deaths and Southern U.S. states form hot spot
article.body: The global tally for confirmed cases of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 climbed above 17.3 million on Friday, according to data aggregated by Johns Hopkins University, and the death toll rose to 673,568. At least 10.2 million people have recovered. The U.S. case tally climbed to 4.49 million and the death toll rose to 152,070, indicating another 2,000 fatalities have occurred since the toll passed 150,000 late Wednesday. Dr. Deborah Birx, coordinator of the White House Task Force created to manage the pandemic, said on Fox News that there is a "very serious pandemic" in Southern states. She named Kentucky, Tennessee, southern Ohio, Missouri, Iowa, Kansas and Nebraska as new trouble spots, along with others that already had problems, including Washington, Oregon, California, Idaho, Utah, and Colorado. Brazil is second to the U.S. with 2.6 million cases and 91,263 deaths. India is third measured by cases at 1.6 million, followed by Russia with 838,461 and South Africa with 482,169. The U.K. has 303,913 cases and 46,84 fatalities, the highest in Europe and third highest in the world. China, where the illness was first reported late last year, has 87,610 cases, and 4,661 fatalities.
